titlestmt.title: Genesis : electronic edition

filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of the Genesis manuscript from the Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens.
In the last year of his life, Blake began an illuminated manuscript of the biblical Book of Genesis for his patron, John Linnell. Of its eleven large leaves, probably cut from Whatman Imperial-sized wove paper, the first two are title pages. The text on leaves 3-11 closely follows chapters 1-4 of the King James Bible, decorated with sketched headpieces, tailpieces, and interlinear designs, with chapter headings of Blake’s own invention that align the biblical creation narrative with his myth of creation, division, and forgiveness. His insertion of “adamah” after most appearances of “ground” in the English text shows Blake’s (and his patron’s) engagement with the original Hebrew, underscores Blake’s view that the creation of the first man was a descent into materiality, and suggests that Adam was originally androgynous because “adamah” is a feminine noun.
Like the title pages of a number of Blake’s early illuminated books, his lettering of the Genesis titles is closely integrated with the illustrations. The reason for variant title pages is not clear, though perhaps Linnell responded unfavorably to the first version (our object 1) and requested the more elegant second version. The main text was composed in six stages, beginning with horizontal lines to guide the lettering. Then Blake drafted the biblical text in light pencil—in a style that mimics the Gothic lettering of medieval illuminated manuscripts—and composed the chapter headings. In subsequent stages he overwrote his earlier work in darker pencil, red and green ink, and occasional gold leaf. Thus Blake revised his preliminary intentions with forms evolving on the same matrix.
Blake’s use of headpiece and tailpiece pairings to denote chapter divisions conforms to eighteenth-century conventions for illustrated books and follows the format of his early illuminated books, such as The Book of Thel (1789) and Visions of the Daughters of Albion (1793). Taken together, the headpieces and chapter headings provide visual and verbal introductions to each chapter that signal Blake’s reinterpretations of the narrative.
The unfinished state of the Genesis designs offers insights into Blake’s method of graphic composition. There is no obvious sequence to the development of the designs. Those on leaves 3–5 have some coloring, including green, over the initial pencil sketches, suggesting that Blake added washes as he overwrote the penciled text in green. The designs on leaves 6–11 are noticeably rougher and uncolored, like the texts on these leaves. Blake clearly did not finish designs before moving on to start others, probably intending to return later to develop his preliminary drawings. The compositional process was evidently non-linear, spontaneous, and rapid.
The manuscript, left unfinished at Blake’s death in August 1827, leaves off with his interpretation of the story of Cain as an exemplary tale of forgiveness, a major theme in his later writings.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, colorist. Blake invented, executed, and colored the designs and delineated both the designs and the text, taken from the King James Bible. He also made changes in the King James text; see the textual transcription and editors' notes. Blake is the author of the chapter headings in objects 3, 6, 8, and 10. For a list of substantive differences between Blake's manuscript and the King James Bible, see Crosby and Essick pages 11-13.
objdescid.compdate: 1827Butlin 828 dates the manuscript to c. 1826-27, but Crosby and Essick say work was not begun until 1827 (Crosby and Essick page 30).

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 38.1 x 28.0 cm. and 37.8 x 27.2 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 38.1 x 28.0 cm. and 37.8 x 27.2 cm.Each leaf has two contiguous deckled edges and appears to be a quarter of a sheet measuring approximately 76 x 56 cm. in total, the dimensions of James Whatman's "Imperial"-size paper (Crosby and Essick page 31).
objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, water color, and shell goldIllustrations are in pencil, with pen and water color in objects 1-5. The text has been written in pencil; often a layer of lighter pencil is visible beneath a darker layer. The text in objects 1 and 2 (the two title pages) also shows the application of a gray-black wash and red water color. Much of the penciled text has been written over in red ink in objects 3-5; green tinting has been applied to the text, presumably at a later stage than the red ink, in objects 3-5 and part of object 6. Shell gold (powdered gold mixed in water with a glue or gum binder) has been added to objects 2 (second title page) and 3. See Crosby and Essick pages 31-32, 36.
objinfo.inkcolor: See the note on medium, above.
objinfo.watermark: "J WHATMAN / TURKEY MILL / 1821" and "J WHATMAN / 1826"The 1821 watermark appears only on object 1, and the 1826 watermark appears on objects 2 and 7. The leaf bearing the 1821 watermark was cut from different stock than the leaves bearing the 1826 watermark (Crosby and Essick pages 31, 49n70).
objinfo.framelines: 1 Object 1 has one framing line, drawn in pencil. Object 2 has an incomplete framing line, drawn roughly in pencil, that surrounds only the upper part of the illustration.

provenance.name: Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by John Linnell (although Linnell may not have taken possession until after Blake's death); sold by the Linnell estate, Christie's, 15 March 1918, lot 192 (£157.10s. to George D. Smith acting for Henry E. Huntington).

repository.institution: Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens

objnote.p: Crosby and Essick conclude that this title page was created before the title page shown in object 2 (page 36).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is compositionally arranged around the title letters and eight human, or at least semi-human figures. The division of the title into three lines may be an allusion to the Trinity, also depicted visually. At the top of the design is a nude, male striding figure, with prominent buttocks and extended arms, raised horizontally, moving left to right. The figure is seen from behind and his head appears to face left. This is the Holy Ghost. Either side of the Holy Ghost are lightly sketched wings. The light wavy pencil lines either side of the wings may depict the firmament or heaven. The figure below and to the left of the Holy Ghost, and next to the "N" of the title, faces forward and is kneeling in a sphere. This figure is male and wears a tight fitting garment. The figure has long, wild hair and a pointed chin or possibly a short beard. This is Christ, God the Son. His left arm extends horizontally to the right, over the top of the "N," and his left hand, palm downward, may be touching the raised right hand of the figure below. God the Son's right arm is bent slightly at the elbow and partially rests on his left thigh. His left leg is bent at the knee and his left foot is visible. God the Son kneels on his right knee and he may be looking right, although his eyes are only slits. The figure to the right of God the Son occupies a mandorla and is male with long, wild hair and a long beard. This is God the Father. He faces forward and is wearing a long flowing robe. His right arm is raised vertically and is bent slightly at the elbow. His right hand is palm up and his left arm is at his side. His left knee may be bent slightly and the pencil and ink lines below the robe suggest feet. The wavy pencil and water color lines above and below the mandorla may represent water. The positioning of God the Father's arms, his right arm counterbalancing his left, suggests that he is dividing the waters under the firmament (or sky) from the waters above the firmament as described in Genesis 1:7. In the lower center of the design is a standing nude, male figure with curly hair, facing forward. This is Adam. His head and upper torso are surrounded by a large halo. A few lines emanating from the halo suggest that it may also be a radiant sun behind Adam. Adam extends both arms, his right arm is raised vertically and in his right hand he may be touching the left hand of the figure above and to the left. Adam's head is tilted back and to the left slightly. He appears to be looking up. Adam's left arm is raised horizontally at 135 degrees. His legs are bent slightly at the knee and he is standing on a convex arc that represents the surface of the Earth. The letter "I" in the title covers his loins, almost like a loincloth. Beneath Adam, four possibly nude creatures are pictured with flames above their heads. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by a few serpentine splashes of blue wash, or on the Earth, as the green patches of coloring might suggest. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The leftmost figure faces forward and both arms are raised vertically. The fingers on the right hand are spread and its head is tilted back slightly. This creature's legs appear to be bent and it is possibly kneeling. The second figure from the left faces forward and appears to have its arms bent across the chest, with hand in an attitude of supplication or possibly surprise. The second figure from the right faces forward,with the head facing left, and its right arm is raised vertically. The fingers of its right hand appear to be spread. Its left arm is by its side and may be supporting the creature. The left leg appears to be bent at the knee. The rightmost figure faces forward and to the left. Its right arm is raised vertically and the fingers of its right hand are spread. This creature's eyes are open and it looks up and to the left. Wavy pencil lines below these four creatures probably represent water. Light wavy pencil lines either side of these creatures may represent smoke or clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the design is a nude, male striding (and perhaps soaring) figure with prominent buttocks and extended arms, raised horizontally, moving left to right. The figure is seen from behind and his head appears to face left. This is the Holy Ghost. Either side of the Holy Ghost are lightly sketched wings. The light wavy pencil lines either side of the wings may depict the firmament.

The figure below and to the left of the Holy Ghost, and next to the "N" of the title, faces forward and is kneeling in a sphere. This figure is male and wears a tight fitting garment. The figure has long, wild hair and a pointed chin or possibly a short beard. This is Christ, God the Son. His left arm extends horizontally to the right, over the top of the "N" and his left hand, palm downward, may be touching the raised right hand of the figure below. God the Son's right arm is bent slightly at the elbow and partially rests on his left thigh. His left leg is bent at the knee and his left foot is visible. God the Son kneels on his right knee and he may be looking right, although his eyes are only slits.

The figure to the right of God the Son occupies a mandorla and is male with long, wild hair and a long beard. This is God the Father. He faces forward and is wearing a long flowing robe. His right arm is raised vertically and is bent slightly at the elbow. His right hand is palm up and his left arm is at his side. His left knee may be bent slightly and the pencil and ink lines below the robe suggest feet. The wavy pencil and water color lines above and below the mandorla may represent water. The positioning of God the Father's arms, his right arm counterbalancing his left, suggests that he is dividing the waters under the firmament (or sky) from the waters above the firmament as described in Genesis 1:7.

In the lower center of the design is a standing nude, male figure with curly hair, facing forward. This is Adam. His head and upper torso are surrounded by a large halo. A few lines emanating from the halo suggest that it may also be a radiant sun behind Adam. Adam extends both arms, his right arm is raised vertically and in his right hand may touch the left hand of the figure above and to the left. Adam's head is tilted back and to the left slightly. He appears to be looking up. Adam's left arm is raised horizontally at 135 degrees. His legs are bent slightly at the knee and he is standing on a convex arc that represents the surface of the Earth. The letter "I" in the title covers his loins, almost like a loincloth.

Beneath Adam, four possibly nude creatures are pictured with flames above their heads. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by a few serpentine splashes of blue wash, or on the Earth, as the green patches of coloring might suggest. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The leftmost figure faces forward and both arms are raised vertically. The fingers on the right hand are spread and its head is tilted back slightly. This creature's legs appear to be bent and drawn up, it is possibly kneeling. The second figure from the left faces forward and appears to have its arms bent across the chest, with hand in an attitude of supplication or possibly surprise. The second figure from the right faces forward,with the head facing left, and its right arm is raised vertically. The fingers of its right hand appear to be spread. Its left arm is by its side and may be supporting the creature. The left leg appears to be bent at the knee. The rightmost figure faces forward and to the left. Its right arm is raised vertically and the fingers of its right hand are spread. This creature's eyes are open and it looks up and to the left.
Wavy pencil lines below these four creatures probably represent water. Light wavy pencil lines either side of these creatures may represent smoke or clouds.
The convex pencil arc that Adam is standing on may represent the surface of the Earth.

The title, "GENESIS," is divided into three parts, possibly indicating the Trinity. The letter shapes suggest Gothic art. The central horizontal of both letters "E" terminate in a fleur-de-lis; the "I" suggests a pillar. The text is integrated into the design.

objnote.p: Crosby and Essick suggest that the differences in style, coloring, and brushwork between the first and second title pages may reveal Blake's desire to suit the preferences of his sponsor, John Linnell, more fully in the latter design (page 40).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is compositionally arranged around the title letters and eight human, or at least semi-human figures. The division of the title into three lines may be an allusion to the Trinity, also depicted visually. At the top of the design is a nude, male striding figure, with prominent buttocks and extended arms, raised horizontally, moving left to right. The figure is seen from behind and his head appears to face right. This is the Holy Ghost. Either side of the Holy Ghost are lightly sketched wings. The light wavy pencil lines either side of the wings may depict the firmament (or heaven). The figure below and to the left of the Holy Ghost, and next to the "N" of the title, faces forward in a cruciform pose. This figure is male and wears a flowing diaphanous robe. The figure has long hair and a short beard. This is Christ, God the Son. His head face right and he may be looking. Both arms are raised horizontally, palms down. In his left hand, God the Son holds the end of a scroll. His right leg is bent slightly at the knee and his right foot is on tip toe. He may be hovering. The figure to the right of God the Son occupies a mandorla and is male with long hair and a long beard. This is God the Father. He faces forward and is wearing a long flowing robe. His right arm is raised vertically. His right hand is palm up and his left arm is at his side. His left knee may be bent slightly. The wavy pencil and water color lines above and below the mandorla may represent water. The positioning of God the Father's arms, his right arm counterbalancing his left, suggests that he is dividing the waters under the firmament (sky) from the waters above the firmament as described in Genesis 1:7. In the central area between the upper two lines of the title letters, "G E / N E," are two palm trees. The title letters are decorated with flowering vegetation. The upper arm of the "G" incorporates a large green leaf. Three funnel-shaped forms, possibly seed pods of the lotus, dangle from the lower horizontal arm of the "G." The right vertical of the "G" is formed like a sheaf of grain with grain tassels upper left. The "E" contains three blooming roses and possibly blades of grass or grain. The "N" contains a serpentine stem that terminates in a five- or six-petal bloom, perhaps a lotus flower. The second "E" includes serpentine tendrils and a star-shaped blossom, possibly the lily of Calvary. The final three letters, "S I S," are devoid of flowers. Both letters "S" are composed of sheafs or shafts of grain or grass. The first "S" also contains three ovoid shapes on the upper left. The "I" is depicted as a classical pillar with a curving, circular flourish at the top left. In the lower center of the design is a standing nude, male figure with curly hair, facing forward. This is Adam. His head and upper torso are surrounded by a large halo. Lines emanating from the halo suggest that it may also be a radiant sun behind Adam. Adam extends both arms; his right arm is raised vertically and in his right hand he holds the same scroll held by God the Son. Adam's head faces to the left slightly. Adam's left arm is raised horizontally, bent at the elbow, and his left hand is palm up. His legs are bent slightly at the knee, with his left foot on tiptoe. He is standing on a convex arc that represents the surface of the Earth. Beneath Adam are four possibly nude creatures. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by the wavy pencil lines a black washes below them. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The body of the leftmost figure faces forward and his head faces right in profile. The creature is wearing a crown and a flame-like tongue flicks out of its open mouth. It is looking upward and to the right. Its left arm is raised vertically and is bent at the elbow. This arm is covered is scales. The left hand is palm up. The creature's right breast is covered in scales. Its right arms extands downward and the right palm faces downward. The creature is sitting and the right arm appears to be supporting its upper body. The creature's legs are together and are bent. The body of the second figure from the left faces forward and its head faces right. It has a bird-like head with curved beak and large oval eye looking up and right. It is wearing a crown and its left arm is bent across the chest. Its right arm is by its side and may be bent at the elbow(?). The creature's legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting position. The body of second figure from the right faces forward and to the right. The creature's head face forward and slightly to the left. The figure has short curly hair or fur on its head, shoulders and neck. This figure's head suggests a lion. Its eyes and mouth are open and his tongue is visible. The creature's arms are across its chest and its hands are in a position of prayer or supplication. Its legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting posture. The body of the rightmost figure faces forward and to the right while the head faces forward and to the left. This creature has a cow- or ox-like head with two curved horns, two open eyes and large nostrils. This creature is looking to the left. The creature's arms are across its chest and its hands are raised, palms vertical, in a gesture that suggests surprise. Its legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting posture. Wavy pencil lines below these four creatures probably represent water. Behind the rightmost and leftmost creatures are two fruit-bearing trees with thick trunks and leafy branches. The tree on the left of the design bears ovoid-shaped fruit while the tree on the right of the design bears grape-like clusters of fruits. These trees represent the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil and the Tree of Life.

Beneath Adam are four possibly nude creatures. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by the wavy pencil lines a black washes below them. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The body of the leftmost figure faces forward and his head faces right in profile. The creature is wearing a crown and a flame-like tongue flicks out of its open mouth. It is looking upward and to the right. Its left arm is raised vertically and is bent at the elbow. Beneath Adam are four possibly nude creatures. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by the wavy pencil lines a black washes below them. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The body of the second figure from the left faces forward and its head faces right. It has a bird-like head with feathered face, curved beak and large oval eye looking up and right. It is wearing a crown and its left arm is bent across the chest. Its right arm is by its side and may be bent at the elbow(?). The creature's legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting position.

Beneath Adam are four possibly nude creatures. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by the wavy pencil lines a black washes below them. These figures have distinct humanoid features. The body of second figure from the right faces forward and to the right. The creature's head faces forward and slightly to the left. The figure has short curly hair or fur on its head, shoulders and neck. Its face suggests a lion. Its eyes and mouth are open and its tongue is visible. The creature's arms are across its chest and its hands are in a position of prayer or supplication. Its legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting posture.

Beneath Adam are four possibly nude creatures. They may be sitting or kneeling in water, as indicated by the wavy pencil lines a black washes below them. These figures have distinct humanoid features.The body of the rightmost figure faces forward and to the right while the head faces forward and to the left. This creature has a cow- or ox-like head with two curved horns, two open eyes and large nostrils. This creature is looking to the left. The creature's arms are across its chest and its hands are raised with palms vertical in a gesture that suggests surprise. Its legs are together and are drawn up in a sitting posture.
Wavy pencil lines below these four creatures probably represent water.
The convex pencil arc that Adam is standing on may represent the surface of the Earth.

Behind the rightmost and leftmost creatures are two fruit-bearing trees with thick trunks and leafy branches. The tree on the left of the design bears ovoid-shaped fruit while the tree on the right of the design bears grape-like clusters of fruits. These trees represent the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil and the Tree of Life.

In the central area between the upper two lines of the title letters, "G E / N E," are two palm trees. The title letters are decorated with flowering vegetation. The upper arm of the "G" incorporates a large green leaf. Three funnel-shaped forms, possibly seed pods of the lotus, dangle from the lower horizontal arm of the "G." The right vertical of the "G" is formed like a sheaf of grain with grain tassels upper left. The "E" contains three blooming roses and perhaps blades of grass or grain. The "N" contains are serpentine stem that terminates in a five- or six-petal bloom, perhaps a lotus flower. The second "E" includes serpentine tendrils and a star-shaped blossom with a prominent stamen that could be a lily of Calvary. The final three letters, "S I S," are devoid of flowers. Both letters "S" are composed of sheafs or shafts of grain or grass. The first "S" also contains three ovoid shapes on the upper left.
The title letters are separated into three units, suggestive of the Trinity. The letter forms suggest Gothic art. The "I" is shaped like a classical pillar.

desc.objtitle: The Creation of the Natural Man, Object 3 (Butlin 828.3)

objnote.p: This object contains red and green ink as well as pencil markings. Crosby and Essick note that the "partly erased" pencil writing visible around the chapter heading suggests that Blake initially wrote Genesis verses 1-2 higher on the page than in his later writing (page 7n). Crosby and Essick call attention to underwriting such as this in the manuscript but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts a bearded deity in the act of creation. In the center of the design is a male, possibly nude, facing forward, with long beard and hair. This is God the Father in the act of creation. With his left hand, this figure points downward. His right arm is bent upward and the right palm faces outward in a gesture of benediction. Either side of this central figure are the heads and upper bodies of two, possibly male, attendants with curly hair. The figure on the right has its left arm raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees with the left palm upward. This figure appears to be looking down. The attendant figure on the left is looking downward. Its right arm is raised horizontally at 135 degrees with the left palm upward. Two large wings extend from both attendant figures suggesting that they are angels. Loose pencil strokes immediately below and either side of these figures could represent clouds. The scene probably takes place in heaven.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design is a male, possibly nude, facing forward, with long beard and hair. The figure may be floating, flying, or hovering. With his left hand, this figure points downward. His right arm is bent upward and the right palm faces outward in a gesture of benediction or blessing. This is God the Father in the act of creation.

Either side of this central figure are the heads and upper bodies of two, possibly male, attendants with curly hair. The figure on the right has its left arm raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees with the left palm upward. This figure appears to be looking down. The attendant figure on the left is looking down. Its right arm is raised at 135 degrees with the left palm upward. Two large wings extend from both attendant figures suggesting that they are angels. These figures may be flying, floating, or hovering.
Curving lines below, left, and right of the figures may be clouds. The scene probably takes place in heaven.

lg.l: Chap:1 & the Earth Bentley reads "I" for "1" (Writings volume 2, page 1344). Illegible underwriting appears in this line in addition to the legible "& the Earth". Crosby and Essick note that the "[f]ragmentary and partly erased" underwriting in the upper part of this object suggests Blake initially wrote verses 1-2 in the area now occupied by the headpiece illustration, chapter heading, and chapter title (page 7n). See also Crosby and Essick page 32.

l.note: Illegible underwriting in this line in addition to the legible "& the Spirit". Crosby and Essick note that the "[f]ragmentary and partly erased" underwriting in the upper part of this object suggests Blake initially wrote verses 1-2 in the area now occupied by the headpiece illustration, chapter heading, and chapter title (page 7n). See also Crosby and Essick page 32.

lg.l: The Creation of the Natural Man.
1In the beginning God created the heavens and the earthThe King James Bible reads "the heaven and" rather than "the heavens and" (Crosby and Essick page 11).
2And the earth was without form and void. and darkness was upon the face
of the deep & the spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters
3And God said Let there be light and there was light
4And God saw the light that it was good & God divided the light from the darkness
5And God called the light day & the darkness he called night & the evening & the
morning were the first day.
6And God said Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters and Let
it divide the waters from the waters

objnote.p: This object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Ruled lines, drawn in pencil, are visible in lines 9-14 of this object.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The three major designs on this leaf appear to be compositionally related, with each panel representing an aspect of creation. At the top of the leaf are three winged, possibly male, figures. Above these figures are four six-pointed stars. Between the three figures are two circle shapes, possibly representing the sun and the moon. The leftmost figure faces to the right, in profile, and has long hair. He is wearing a long flowing robe or gown and his arms are raised at 45 degrees. The central figure faces away and his arms are raised at 135 degrees. His left leg is bent and his left is on tiptoe. The rightmost figure faces forward, has long, wild hair and a pointed chin. His arms are raised at 45 degrees. He is wearing a long diaphanous robe or gown and his left leg may be slightly bent. Wavy lines beneath these figures could represent waters. A very light convex arc, representing the surface of the Earth, appears behind and on either side of the central figure.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the leaf are three winged, possibly male, figures. The leftmost figure faces to the right, in profile, and has long hair. He is wearing a long flowing robe or gown and his arms are raised at 45 degrees.
At the top of the leaf are three winged, possibly male, figures. The central figure faces away and his arms are raised at 135 degrees. His left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe.

At the top of the leaf are three winged, possibly male, figures. The rightmost figure faces forward, has long, wild hair and possibly a beard. His arms are raised at 45 degrees. He is wearing a long diaphanous robe or gown and his left leg may be slightly bent. This could be Christ, God the Son.

There are four six-pointed stars located above the winged figures. Between the these figures are two circular shapes, possibly representing planets, or the sun and the moon. The circle on the left includes a suggestion of a crescent moon.
Wavy lines beneath these figures could represent waters. A very light convex arc, representing the surface of the Earth, appears behind and either side of the central figure

illustration.illusobjdesc: The middle design panel depicts three soaring male figures in a recessional configuration above waves and marine animals. The three figures are flying left to right. The front figure is wearing a long flowing robe, has long hair and a pointed chin. Lines above the shoulder may suggest a wing. This is Christ, God the Son. His left arm is raised horizontally and extends to the right. He may be looking right although his eyes are only slits. Only the head of the second figure is visible. He may have long hair and a beard. His eyes appear open and he may be looking right. Only the outline of the head of the third figure is visible. Below these figures are rolling waves and a leaping dolphin. Very sketchy lines either side of the waves may be placeholders for more sea creatures.

component.illusobjdesc: The three figures are flying left to right. The front figure is wearing a long flowing robe, has long hair and a pointed chin. Pencil strokes above the shoulder may suggest a wing. This is Christ, God the Son. His left arm is raised horizontally and extends to the right. He may be looking right although his eyes are only slits. Only the head of the second figure is visible. He may have long hair and a beard. His eyes appear open and he may be looking right. Only the outline of the head of the third figure is visible. This may be the Trinity, with Christ as the frontmost figure, God the Father in the center, and the Holy Ghost.

Below the soaring figures are rolling waves and a leaping dolphin with a prominent fin. The animal's eye and mouth are open. Sketchy pencil lines either side of the dolphin could be placeholders for more marine creatures.
Below the soaring figures are rolling waves.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lower design panel comprises three clusters of pencil lines with a broken line connecting them. The line may depict the surface of the Earth. The central cluster of lines are close to the line and may be one or more of the "creeping things" described in the text immediately above. The cluster of lines on the right contains an ovoid shape with smaller ovoids inside. This may be the beginnings of a face. The cluster of lines on the left suggest more living creatures, possibly "kind cattle."

component.illusobjdesc: Clusters of pencil lines connected by a central, broken line, may depict the "living creatures," "kind cattle" and "creeping thing" described in the text immediately above. The cluster on the left may be a placeholder for "kind cattle." The central cluster may be a placeholder for "creeping thing" due to the proximity to the broken line. The right hand cluster depicts two small ovoids inside a larger ovoid and may be a face.
An broken horizontal line, possibly representing the surface of the Earth, connects the cluster of pencil lines.

objnote.p: This object contains red and green ink as well as a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. Beginning in verse 27, the text in green ink is often in a slightly different position than the pencil writing beneath it (Crosby and Essick page 7n). In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines, drawn in pencil, in this object are double, fragmented, or partially erased. In some cases the ruled lines bisect or lie above the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts four standing male figures in dynamic attitudes. The nude figure on the left has short hair and is facing right in profile. This may be Adam. His arms are raised horizontally and bent upward with fingers spread and palms up. This figure's left leg extends back and is bent slightly at the knee. His left foot is on tiptoe. On the right of the design are three gowned figures in similar poses. All three face forward and left, and their arms are raised. Their left arms are raised at 135 degrees and their right arms are raised at 45 degrees, with palms up. The rightmost figure may have short hair. The central figure has long hair and a beard. This may be God the Father. The leftmost figure of this tripartite grouping, possibly the Trinity, may also have long hair. All three figures may be holding objects in their raised left hands. Swirling pencil lines either side of the four figures may represent clouds. The pencil lines beneath the figures may represent the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: The nude figure on the left has short hair and is facing right in profile. His arms are raised horizontally and bent upward with fingers spread and palms up. This could be Adam. His left leg extends back and is bent slightly at the knee. He may be walking. The left foot is on tiptoe.

On the right of the design are three gowned figures in similar poses. All three face forward and left, and their arms are raised. Their left arms are raised at 135 degrees and their right arms are raised at 45 degrees, with palms up. All three figures may be holding an object in their raised left hands. The rightmost figure may have short hair. The central figure has long hair and a beard. This may be God the Father. The leftmost figure of this tripartite grouping may also have long hair. This may be the Trinity.
Swirling pencil lines either side of the four figures may represent clouds.
The pencil lines beneath the figures may represent the ground.

desc.objtitle: The Natural Man Divided into Male & Female & of the Tree of life & of the Tree of Good & Evil, Object 6 (Butlin 828.6)

objnote.p: The use of green ink in the manuscript stops midway through the first line of verse 5 in this object; from this point forward Blake's text is written only in pencil. The chapter headings and Blake's title are also written in pencil. In addition to dark text in pencil, which has been transcribed here in black font, this object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines, drawn in pencil, in this object are double, fragmented, or partially erased. In some cases the ruled lines bisect or lie above the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts the creation of Adam and Eve. In the center of the design is a nude male, facing forward with arms bent upward with palms up. This is Adam. His head tilts back and to the right slightly. His eyes may be open. Adam's legs are drawn up and he appears to be half sitting and half reclining on a convex arc. Above Adam is a large, possibly male, figure facing forward. Dark pencil lines extending from this figure to the right suggest a beard. This could be God the Father. The figure on the left of the design may be male, faces forward with the head facing left and up. Curved lines left and right of his body indicate wings. The figure's mouth is open and he may be wearing a crown. The figure's legs and arms are bent and he is in a contracted pose. The figure on the right of the design is a nude female, facing forward and to the left. This is Eve. She has long hair; her eyes and mouth may be open. Her arms are bent across her chest, possibly covering her breasts. Her legs extend diagonally to left and appear to touch Adam's left hip or thigh. Above these figures are looping and swirling pencil lines that may represent branches of a tree. Ovoid shapes above the figure on the left may be fruit. Pencil lines either side of the figures may represent tree trunks. Below the figures is a convex arc representing the surface of the Earth.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design is a nude male, facing forward with arms bent upward with palms up. This is Adam. His head tilts back and to the right slightly. His eyes may be open. Adam's legs are drawn up and he appears to be half sitting and half reclining on a convex arc representing the surface of the Earth.

Above Adam is a large, possibly male and gowned, figure facing forward. The figure may be standing or squatting. Dark pencil lines extending from this figure to the right suggest a beard. This may be God the Father.

The figure on the left of the design may be male, faces forward with the head facing left and up. This may be Satan. The figure's mouth is open and he may be wearing a crown. His left eye may be open. The figure's legs and arms are bent and he is in a contracted pose. Curving lines left and right of the figure indicate wings.

The figure on the right of the design is a nude female, facing forward and to the left. This is Eve. She may be floating or hovering. She has long hair, and her eyes and mouth may be open. She is looking at Adam. Her arms are bent across her chest, possibly covering her breasts. Her legs extend diagonally to left and appear to touch Adam's right hip or thigh.

Above the figures are looping and swirling pencil lines that may represent branches of a tree. Ovoid shapes above the winged figure may be fruit. Pencil lines either side of the figures may represent tree trunks.
The convex line below the figures probably represents the surface of the Earth.

objnote.p: This object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. They note that underwriting is visible through verse 21 of this object and that in verses 14 through 17, the underwritten text is in a different position than the text darker text written over it (page 8n). In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines, drawn in pencil, in this object are double, fragmented, or partially erased. In some cases the ruled lines bisect or lie above the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design illustrates Eve's creation and contains five figures. There are three figures at the top of the design in a recessional grouping. These figures are soaring left to right. The front figure is male, has long hair and possibly a beard. He is wearing a long gown. His eye is open and he is looking to the right. His arms are at his sides and the fingers of both hands are spread slightly. Only the heads of the second and third figures in this tripartite grouping are visible. They face right. This may be the Trinity. The figure below this group is a nude female with long hair and prominent breasts. She faces forward and to the left. She appears to be hovering soaring left to right. This is Eve. Her left arm is raised horizontally and is bent upward. Her left hand may be supporting her head. Eve's leg extend diagonally to the left with her left foot touching the chest of the figure below. This is Adam, supine with right arm by his side. Adam's head is tilted back. Pencil lines across Adam's chest suggest an incision. Below Adam are loose pencil lines that may depict vegetation or the ground. Curved pencil lines above, below, and to the right of Eve's head may depict clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures at the top of the design in a recessional grouping. These figures are soaring left to right. The front figure is male, has long hair and a beard. This may be God the Father. He is wearing a long gown. Pencil lines above his shoulder suggest a wing. His eye is open and he is looking to the right. His arms are at his sides and the fingers of both hands are spread slightly. Only the heads of the second and third figures in this tripartite grouping are visible. They face right. This may be the Trinity.

The figure below this group is a nude female with long hair and prominent breasts. She faces forward and to the left. Her genitals are visible. She appears to be soaring, floating, flying or hovering from left to right. This is Eve. Her left arm is raised horizontally and is bent at 90 degrees. Her left hand may be supporting her head. Eve's legs extend diagonally to the left with her left foot touching the chest of the figure below.

The lower figure is Adam, supine with right arm at his side. The fingers of his right hand may be spread. His right palm faces down. His legs extend to the right. His right leg may be slightly bent. Adam has curly hair and his head is tilted back. Pencil lines across Adam's chest suggest an incision or wound.

Below Adam are loose pencil lines that may depict vegetation or the ground. Curved pencil lines above, below, and to the right of Eve's head may depict clouds. Two curving forms below Adam's legs might be flames.

desc.objtitle: Of the Sexual Nature & its Fall into Generation & death, Object 8 (Butlin 828.8)

objnote.p: This object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines, drawn in pencil, in this object are double, fragmented, or partially erased. In some cases the ruled lines bisect or lie above the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts the judgement of Adam and Eve. On the left of the design are two nude figures. The leftmost figure is Adam. He faces forward and his head is turned to the right in profile. He is kneeling. His right arm is bent behind his back and his left arm is bent upward over his chest, palm possibly vertical. He may be looking at the figure immediately to his right. This is Eve. She faces forward and her head is tilted back and to the right. She has long hair and is kneeling. Her left arm is by her side and bent upward with her hand covering her breasts. Eve's right arm is at her side and bent slightly. Her right hand covers her genitals. She appears to be looking up and to the right. On the right of the design is a tree with a large, thick trunk. Loose pencil lines above and around the trunk may represent branches and leaves. Two ovoid shapes hang from one of the branches. These ovoids are probably fruits, indicating that this is the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil. At the base of the tree is a large-headed serpent. It faces left and its mouth and eye are open. It may be looking at Adam and Eve. Between Adam and Eve's knees is a semi-round shape with a short vertical line. This is the forbidden fruit, partially eaten by Adam and Eve. The curving lines upper right may be a placeholder for God the Father.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left of the design are two nude figures. The leftmost figure is Adam. He faces forward and his head is turned to the right, in profile. He is kneeling. His right arm is bent behind his back; his left arm is bent upward over his chest, palm possibly vertical. His right foot is visible. He may be looking at the figure immediately to his right.

The second figure from the left is Eve. She faces forward and her head is tilted back and to the right. She has long hair and is kneeling. Her left arm is by her side and bent upward with her hand covering her breasts. Eve's right arm is at her side and is bent slightly. Her right hand covers her genitals. She appears to be looking up and to the right.
Lying at the base of the tree is a large-headed serpent. This is Satan It faces left and its mouth and eye are open. It may be looking at Adam and Eve.

On the right of the design is a tree with a large, thick trunk. Loose pencil lines above and around the trunk may be placeholders for branches and leaves. Two ovoid shapes hang from one of the branches. These ovoids are probably fruits, indicating that this is the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil.
Between Adam and Eve's knees in a semi-round shape with a short vertical line. This is the forbidden fruit, partially eaten by Adam and Eve.
Curving lines upper right may be a placeholder for God the Father in the act of judgement.

objnote.p: This object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines, drawn in pencil, in this object bisect or lie above the text. The last several lines of text in this object overlap with pencil markings that appear to belong to the illustration visible below or to another drawing of Blake's (Crosby and Essick page 9n).

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts the expulsion and consists of two groups of vaguely defined shapes, on the lower left and upper right, connected by large curling lines, possibly flames. The two forms on the lower left may be placeholders from Adam and Eve. Three of the four circular shapes upper right may represent heads of the Trinity, with the fourth and lowest circle indicating part of the body of one member of the group.

component.illusobjdesc: This design depicts the expulsion and consists of two groups of vaguely defined shapes, on the lower left and upper right, connected by large curling lines, The two forms on the lower left may be placeholders from Adam and Eve.

This design depicts the expulsion and consists of two groups of vaguely defined shapes, on the lower left and upper right, connected by large curling lines. Some of the swirling lines may be flames.

desc.objtitle: How generation & death took Possession of the Natural Man, Object 10 (Butlin 828.10)

objnote.p: This object contains a number of light pencil markings, some of which are legible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased or overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to this underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurrences. Traces of underwriting in lines 5 through 13 suggest that these lines shifted location somewhat between writings (Crosby and Essick 9n). In this transcription, legible underwriting has been transcribed when it differs significantly from Blake's later writing in content or position. When the underwritten text is identical but appears in a different location, gray font has been used to distinguish underwriting from other text. Please note that gray font is also used in Blake Archive transcriptions to describe unclear or conjectural text. Some of the ruled lines in this object are double, fragmented, or partially erased. In some cases the ruled lines bisect or lie above the text. The chapter heading in this object overlaps slightly with Blake's illustration.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts Cain fleeing in the aftermath of Abel's murder. There are two groupings of figures on either side of the design. At the lower edge of the illustration, sketchy horizontal lines may depict a grave. Above the grave are loose, curving horizontal lines suggesting a supine figure, probably the murdered Abel. The cluster of lines on the left are Abel's head resting on the knee or thigh of one of the two kneeling figures. These are Adam and Eve. The figure on the left faces right in profile; the figure to the right appears to face forward with head down. On the right of the design is a figure facing right, in profile, with his left arm raised vertically and palm facing right or possibly pointing upward. This is probably Cain fleeing. Cain's legs are apart and are bent at the knees. His right leg is extended back and his right foot may be on tiptoe. He is running. The cluster of lines above and slightly to the left of this figure depict a soaring or hovering figure. A circle suggests a head and horizontal lines extending left suggest the outline of a body. This may be God.

component.illusobjdesc: Loose, curving horizontal lines in the lower central and left ares of the design suggest a supine figure, probably the murdered Abel. The cluster of lines on the left are Abel's head resting on the knee or thigh of one of the two kneeling figures. These are Adam and Eve. The figure on the left faces right; the figure to the right appears to face forward with head bent down. The right arm of the figure on the left is at his or her side. This figure may be holding the supine figure.

On the right of the design is a figure facing right, in profile, with their left arm raised vertically and palm vertical or possibly Cain's index finger pointing upward. This is probably Cain fleeing. Cain's legs are apart and are bent at the knees. His right leg is extended back and his right foot may be on tiptoe. He is running.

The cluster of lines above and slightly to the left of this figure depicts a soaring or hovering figure(s). A circle suggests a head and horizontal lines extending left suggest the outline of a body. This may be God.
At the lower edge of the illustration, sketchy horizontal lines may depict a grave.

lg.l: V As Crosby and Essick note, the "V" in "Chap IV" is double (page 9n). The "V" transcribed in this line lies above the "V" that has been transcribed in the following line. It is possible that "I" has been written twice as well.
ChapIV

Ch – VHow generation & death took Possession of the Natural ManBlake appears to have written "Ch – V" rather than "Ch – IV" by mistake (Crosby and Essick 9n). Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1345) and Erdman (page 688) read "generation" as "Generation" and "death" as "Death"; Bentley reads "Possession" as "possession" (Writings volume 2, page 1345). The underwriting in this line is the same as the darker text written over it (Crosby and Essick page 9n).

& of the forgiveness of Sins written upon the Murderers forhead forehead
"forhead": i.e., presumably, "forehead". Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1345) and Erdman (page 688) read "forgiveness" as "Forgiveness" and "forhead" as "Forehead".

objnote.p: This object has 23 ruled lines. Only the first three of these contain text, suggesting Blake left the work unfinished. This object also contains light pencil markings, some of which are visible. These appear to be remnants of Blake's first writing that were erased of overwritten at a later stage. Crosby and Essick call attention to the underwriting but do not transcribe it (page 1); they use textual notes to detail many individual occurences.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts God forgiving Cain. In the center of the design are two male figures facing each other. The figure on the left faces right in profile and is bending forward and down. This is God, wearing a long flowing gown. A leg, possibly left leg, extends back toward the left, and the left foot appears to be on tiptoe. God may be partly kneeling. The right arm of God is at the side of his body and extends to the right and suggests an embrace with the figure to the right. God has long hair and one slit-like eye is visible. God's head is bent down and he appears to be touching the forehead of the figure to the right. This is Cain, who faces left in profile and appears to be kneeling. Cain is wearing a gown and his head is tilted back. One eye is open and he looks up at God. Cain's left arm is raised and bent. His lower arm is vertical and rests on God's upper right arm, suggesting an embrace. Cain's left foot is visible. Below God and Cain is a convex arc representing the surface of the Earth. To the right of the design are a cluster of pencil lines that depict a structure with a steep sloping roof. In front of this structure are the outlines of two figures with bowed heads, facing left. These are Adam and Eve. Above the structure and to the left of God are curving lines that may represent clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: In the center of the design are two male figures facing each other. The figure on the left faces right in profile and is bending forward and down. This is God, wearing a long flowing gown. A leg, possibly the left leg, extends backward, and the left foot appears to be on tiptoe. God may be partly kneeling. The right arm of God, at the side of his body, is bent slightly and extends to the right suggesting an embrace with the figure to the right. God has long hair and one slit-like eye is visible. God's head is bent down and he appears to be touching or kissing the forehead of the figure to the right.

The smaller central figure is Cain, who faces left in profile and is kneeling. Cain is wearing a gown and his head is tilted back. One eye is open and he looks up at God the Father. Cain's left arm is raised and bent. His lower arm is vertical and rests on God's upper right arm, suggesting an embrace. Cain's left foot is visible.

To the right of the design and in front of the steep-roofed structure are the outlines of two figures with lowered heads, facing left. These are Adam and Eve. They appear to be wearing gowns and dark pencil lines on the leftmost figure suggest hands clasped together in prayer or supplication. They may be kneeling.
Below God and Cain is a convex arc representing the surface of the Earth.
Above the structure and to the left of God are curving lines that may represent clouds.
To the right of the design are a cluster of pencil lines that depicts a structure, probably a cottage-like hut or house but possibly a tent, with a steep sloping roof.

lg.l:
15 And the Lord said unto Cain Therefore whosoever slayeth
The King James Bible reads "said unto him, Therefore" rather than "said unto Cain Therefore" (Crosby and Essick page 13).

l.hi: Cain vengeance shall be taken of him sevenfold and the
l.note: The ruled line line bisects much of the text in this line. The King James Bible reads "taken on him" rather than "taken of him" and "And the" rather than "and the" (Crosby and Essick page 13).

l.hi: Lord set a mark upon Cains forehead
l.note: The King James Bible reads "Lord set a mark upon Cain, lest any finding him should should kill him" rather than "Lord set a mark upon Cains forehead" (Crosby and Essick page 13).
